name: PolicyEngine
description: PolicyEngine is a free, open-source app that enables anyone to compute the impact of reforms to taxes and benefits across multiple countries, using open-source microsimulation models.

clearOwnership.clearOwnershipURL: PolicyEngine's about page defines the team structure and oversight: https://policyengine.org/uk/about

documentation:
Each country's microsimulation model has its own documentation website detailing how it models that country's taxes and benefits:

UK: https://policyengine.github.io/policyengine-uk
US: https://policyengine.github.io/policyengine-us
Core microsimulation framework: https://policyengine.github.io/policyengine-core

The PolicyEngine GitHub organisation and repos also have documentation:
https://github.com/policyengine

NonPII.nonPIIAccessMechanism: PolicyEngine handles both custom reform data generated by users (e.g. details of a reform that a user would like to analyse), and user-submitted data about their household (e.g. the number of people in it, and the taxes and benefits they'd like to calculate). Both of these are sent over a REST API in JSON format between the web app and a calculation API, but can also be provided as a Python object in the Python model interface.

bestPractices: PolicyEngine runs unit and integration tests on all repositories
with hundreds of tests run automatically on country tax-benefit models. For example
the PolicyEngine US model runs over 1

200 tests with example household inputs and expected taxes and benefits: https://github.com/PolicyEngine/policyengine-us/actions/runs/4420592329/jobs/7750479966.

PolicyEngine also follows semantic versioning and follows the Keep A Changelog standard: new updates to the repositories require a new changelog entry and that all tests pass.

dataPrivacySecurity.collectsPII: PII data is NOT collected NOT stored and NOT distributed.

userContent.contentManagement: Content is NOT collected NOT stored and NOT distributed.

sdgs.sdg: SDG1: End Poverty in all its forms everywhere
sdgs.relevance:
SDG1: End Poverty in all its forms everywhere

PolicyEngine enables anyone to define and simulate a reform to taxes or benefits, and instantly see the effect on poverty rates, with extensive breakdowns by age group and gender. This means that people or organisations who aim to propose antipoverty policy can quantify the impacts of their policy recommendations, and compare against other policies to refine their proposals to maximise their impact. PolicyEngine also allows users to see how policies would affect deep poverty, defined as having income below half of the regular poverty line in a country. The app has seen usage across the political spectrum, but PolicyEngine is nonpartisan and targets a wide user-base.

For example, the Green Party of England and Wales used PolicyEngine to estimate how their manifesto would affect poverty rates in their report entitled 'Poverty Buster: The impact of the 2019 Green Party manifesto on household incomes and equality'. Available at https://martin-farley.medium.com/poverty-buster-the-impact-of-the-2019-green-party-manifesto-on-household-incomes-and-equality-9663c39b783b.

SDG5: Gender Equity

PolicyEngine promotes gender equity by enabling users to analyse the gender-specific impacts of various tax and benefit policies in its open-source microsimulation models and the change in gender-specific poverty rates on the web app. By providing detailed breakdowns of policy effects on different gender groups, PolicyEngine allows policymakers, researchers, and organizations to design and advocate for policies that promote gender equality and address existing disparities. This empowers users to create more equitable policies, helping to bridge the gender gap in income and economic opportunities.

SDG8: Decent work and economic growth

PolicyEngine supports the creation of decent work and economic growth by facilitating the analysis of policies relating to how taxation and welfare interacts with households' labour choices. Marginal tax rates and issues like 'welfare cliffs' (where an individual suddenly loses entitlement to financial support with a small increase in income) are often missing from policy analyses, but PolicyEngine enables anyone to see how marginal tax rates and welfare cliffs would be affected by different policy reforms, both at the societal level and the household level.

For example, the Centre for Policy Studies used PolicyEngine to model the impacts of a tax cut on labour income, which was taken up by the government and passed into law in 2022. Their full report is available at https://cps.org.uk/research/national-insurance-a-plan-to-blunt-the-pain/.

SDG10: Reduced inequalities

PolicyEngine enables reducing inequalities by providing users with tools to model and analyse the distributional effects of tax and benefit policies. Users can examine the impacts of policies on the income distribution, poverty rates, and inequality measures like the Gini coefficient or the share of income held by the top 10 and 1 percent. This enables policymakers and organisations to design and advocate for policies that reduce disparities within country populations. By providing a comprehensive, data-driven platform for policy analysis, PolicyEngine helps users create targeted policy interventions that can reduce income inequality and promote social, economic, and political inclusion for all.

the Green Party of England and Wales*
(US) the Centre for Growth and Opportunity

the Maryland Child Alliance.
